CatDescriptText: Mr. William Parker, silverman, St. Clair Village and Mrs. Gloria Lee,  housewife, Duquesne Heights, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, May 12, 1962, pg. 13   with question: "Do you think the Kennedy Administration is anti-big business?"  Mr. Parker's answer reads: "I think that he took the right moves against big business.  If he hadn't done anything at this time there's no telling what extent the country would have been in, in the future."  Mrs. Lee's answer reads: "Kennedy isn't against big business because he's a big businessman himself. But he's not going to let people be taken advantage of and this is the reason he acted recently in the case of big steel..."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of William Parker wearing fedora, moustache, and light colored short sleeve polo shirt, standing n front of Bud Saunders Flowers, Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown; Portrait of Gloria Lee wearing light colored sleeveless shirt and wristwatch, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
